Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Extreme water use patterns and their impact on the microbial and chemical ecology of drinking water.

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The COVID-19 pandemic has infected over a million people in the United States to date. Stay-at-home orders and the closing of non-essential businesses have been implemented in many municipalities to limit the spread of COVID-19. An unintentional impact of these interventions is a drastic change in where and how much drinking water is used. For example, water use in commercial buildings has decreased while water use in homes has increased. There is limited understanding of how changes in water use across densely populated cities impact drinking water quality, and what actions must be taken to lower any potential risks. Changes in water use can change the type and number of chemicals or harmful organisms present in the system, affecting water quality and public health. The primary goal of this RAPID project is to understand the effect of drastic changes in water use patterns across residential and commercial locations on the quality of drinking water. Drinking water quality will be monitored at multiple residential and commercial locations in the City of Boston, during and after the pandemic. Results from this study will have a direct impact on post-COVID-19 recovery. Results inform efforts to protect public health and water infrastructure in future scenarios where water use patterns change drastically over short time periods.<br/><br/>Stay-at-home advisories and related cessation of all non-essential businesses in response to the global COVID-19 pandemic have dramatically altered drinking water use patterns across the United States. An unintended consequence of these changes is the potential public health concerns of water non-use. Specifically, water use in commercial buildings has decreased dramatically, leading to extended stagnation and loss of disinfection capacity. Stagnation can lead to the growth of biofilms in plumbing containing opportunistic pathogens or corrosion due to the potential for anoxic/anaerobic conditions. At the same time, water use in homes has increased greatly which may also affect biofilms in building plumbing. The objectives of this RAPID project are to determine the impact of (1) changes in water use patterns on the microbial and chemical ecology of drinking water; and (2) growth of biofilms on the bulk water microbial community as a function of varying water use patterns. The research team will leverage ongoing efforts at chemical and integrated metagenomic monitoring of drinking water in the City of Boston to address the project objectives. In the short-term, this research will generate much-needed data and insights to inform recommissioning strategies. This is particularly important in the short-term as the individuals suffering or recovering from COVID-19 may be exposed to opportunistic respiratory pathogens from drinking water. Results will also inform guidance for water utilities on flushing and disinfecting water that was not used in large commercial buildings during the public heath interventions. In the long term, the ability to compare the impact of extreme changes in water use patterns on the chemical and microbial ecology of drinking water in a full-scale drinking water system has the potential to significantly enhance understanding of the biological stability of drinking water. Thus, results from this study will have a direct impact on post-COVID-19 recovery while also leveraging the current situation to provide lasting advances in drinking water quality management.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drinking water stagnation in building plumbing is associated with a range of deleterious impacts ranging from loss of disinfectant residuals to corrosion to the growth of waterborne pathogens. Most of the research that informs our insights into the effects of stagnation on drinking water and the resultant implications for water safety is derived from simulated experiments or short-term stagnation that capture a narrow range of water use patterns within homes and buildings. While these studies have been extremely valuable, the scope of water use patterns and length of stagnation defined by these are typically narrow. The unprecedented nature of widespread building closures in commercial sectors related to social distancing policies enacted in response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic heightened concerns about the microbiological safety of drinking water post-re-opening; these concerns were exacerbated by the knowledge gap surrounding extended stagnation. This project sought to collect data on the impact of extended stagnation and phased re-opening on the water quality in commercial buildings as compared to residential buildings, where water use was not impacted.

This project included a monthly sampling of drinking water from multiple commercial and residential buildings. This sampling included a short-term flushing profile to assess the impact of flushing on water quality in both commercial and residential buildings. All samples were thoroughly characterized for a range of water quality parameters, both chemical and microbiological, including the quantitation of metals and waterborne pathogens. We found that while long-term stagnation and altered water usage due to stay-at-home advisories did impact drinking water quality, this impact was limited to non-existent when considering waterborne pathogens or metals. For instance, despite widespread concerns about the presence of Legionella pneumophila due to extended stagnation periods, we found no evidence of its presence in water samples collected as part of this study. The impact of extended stagnation was most significant on the microbial communities in the drinking water samples when comparing the commercial and residential buildings. Specifically, the microbial concentrations of the first flush samples were several fold higher in commercial as compared to residential buildings and the microbial community composition between the two was also distinct. While short-term flushing reduced the microbial concentrations in drinking water from commercial buildings, the drinking water microbial communities between the commercial and residential buildings remained distinct. With phased re-opening, the drinking water microbial communities in commercial buildings became increasingly similar to those in residential buildings and within three months, the two microbial communities in flushed samples were not significantly different. This indicates that while short-term flushing post-stagnation can reduce microbial concentrations, it is of limited utility in mitigating the impact of extended stagnation on microbial communities composition in drinking water. Rather, a return to pre-extended stagnation water use patterns and demand was required for the recovery of drinking water microbial communities based on their increased similarity to those in residential buildings.

This project also trained multiple graduate and undergraduate researchers including women engineers and resulted in a full-time job opportunity for a graduate student in an engineering firm. The undergraduate researchers, in particular, were trained in a range of laboratory techniques that are routine in the field of drinking water sampling and drinking water quality monitoring. Outcomes of this research are being integrated into educational modules within water quality management and water treatment curriculum at the research teams' universities. Overall, this project supported the collection and analyses of water quality data associated with a unique set of circumstances due to the COVID-19 pandemic and these data and associated insights will help improve plans and best practices for building water quality management.
